metadata.filename: Maximizing Net Present Value for Resource Constraint Project Scheduling Problems with Payments at Event Occurrences Using Approximate Dynamic Programming.md
metadata.title: Maximizing Net Present Value for Resource Constraint Project Scheduling Problems with Payments at Event Occurrences Using Approximate Dynamic Programming

references.content:

tables.table_title: Table 4 presents the average values of the NPV for the j 30 , j 60 , and j 90 project sets corresponding to the six models for different levels of NC. As NC increases, the average value decreases for each project size, which is logical because, as the complexity of the network increases, it becomes harder for each algorithm to find the best NPV. We see that EDA and ACO used as priority for MC have increased the NPV. We can also note that EDA variant is much resistant to changes in NC. Similarly, Figures 4 and 5 confirm our observation from Table 4.

Table 6 shows the average values of the NPV for the j 30 , j 60 , and j 90 project sets corresponding to the six models for different levels of RS. As the RS increases, the average values of all algorithms increase. In this case, we see that APD_DCS using MC with random priority generated better solutions than with ACO as priority; however, EDA maintained its superiority. The robustness of ADP(-DCS)-EDA in terms of RS is confirmed by Figures 8 and 9 as it consistently outperforms other methods in all different project sizes.
Average values of the NPV for j 30 , j 60 , and j 90 projects for six different algorithms in terms of RS.
